title: Reducing Hallucinations in Language Model-based SPARQL Query Generation Using Post-Generation Memory Retrieval
author: Aditya Sharma (Mila), Luis Lara (Mila), Amal Zouaq (Mila), Christopher J. Pal (Mila, Canada CIFAR AI Chair, Polytechnique Montréal), ...
relevance_why: This paper addresses hallucination issues in generating queries from natural language, which could inform methodologies applicable to audio language modeling tasks in generating structured audio queries.
background: The paper focuses on generating SPARQL queries from natural language questions and mitigating errors caused by the model's tendency to fabricate non-existent identifiers.
contribution: This paper introduces the Post-Generation Memory Retrieval (PGMR) framework to solve hallucination issues in SPARQL query generation, achieving near-complete elimination of incorrect Uniform Resource Identifiers (URIs).

technical_comparison.prior_work: Previous methods often produced incorrect URIs due to reliance solely on internal knowledge of language models.
technical_comparison.novelty: This work improves by incorporating a non-parametric memory retrieval module to validate and replace generated URI labels with accurate ones.

key_innovation: Combines query generation with a memory retrieval approach that separately handles the accuracy of knowledge elements.
real_world_impact: Improves accuracy in knowledge graph querying, enhancing the reliability of applications across various domains that depend on structured data retrieval. No immediate real-world impact.
limitations: Although PGMR successfully reduces hallucinations, the effectiveness still hinges on the underlying model's ability to generate correct query structures.

new_terms.Post-Generation Memory Retrieval (PGMR): **PGMR** is a framework that enhances the generation of structured queries by verifying and correcting identifiers after initial query construction.
